docs.title: hyperc
docs.text:
Break it. Fix it. Document it. Level up.

hack

docs.title: Who Am I
docs.text: I'm hyperc - just a curious person who spends hours breaking things... and learning along the way. I don't like sticking to the surface. If something works, I ask "why?" If something breaks, I ask "how can I break it more?"

docs.title: Research
docs.text:
This section contains technical deep-dives, experiments, and analysis beyond standard write-ups.

Not just exploitation — understanding attack surfaces, patterns, and defensive gaps.

docs.title: 🔍 Active Directory Attack Patterns
docs.text:
Exploring common AD misconfigurations observed across HTB, Pro Labs, and CTF environments.

Topics include:

  • ACL abuse patterns
  • Kerberos delegation abuse
  • Service account exposure
  • Attack path chaining

docs.title: 🧠 Enumeration Strategy Analysis
docs.text:
Comparing automated vs manual enumeration approaches:

  • Nmap vs Rustscan
  • BloodHound data interpretation
  • LDAP query strategies
  • PrivEsc detection patterns

docs.title: 🧪 Lab Experiments
docs.text:
Documenting personal lab experiments:

  • Custom vulnerable AD setups
  • Kerberoasting lab
  • NTLM relay testing
  • Lateral movement simulations

docs.title: 📊 Exploitation Case Studies
docs.text:
Breaking down complex attack chains:

  • Initial foothold → Domain compromise
  • Privilege escalation via misconfigured GPO
  • Credential reuse in segmented networks

docs.title: 🧩 Lessons & Observations
docs.text:
Patterns repeatedly seen across machines:

  • Weak service account hygiene
  • Over-permissioned AD objects
  • Web → AD pivot patterns
  • Misconfigured backup systems

Research is where tradecraft matures.

docs.title: Network Configuration
docs.text:
echo "ip domain" | sudo tee -a /etc/hots

Purpose of this step:

  • Maps the IP address 10.10.10.90 to various hostname formate
  • Required for Kerberos authentication which relies on FQDNs
  • Allows using domain names instead of IP addresses in commands
